regions.name: Ahvenanmaa
regions.regionDescription: The coat of arms of Åland depicts a golden red deer set against a blue background, topped with a traditional Swedish-style comital coronet. The coat of arms originally designed for Åland (two roe deer with nine roses) was mistakenly used by Öland (Sweden), and Åland instead adopted Öland's red deer design. This mix-up was not discovered until the 1940s, after Åland had been ceded to Finland. Finnish heraldic authorities chose not to correct the mistake, allowing Åland to keep the red deer. To prevent further confusion, Sweden modified Öland's coat of arms by adding a red collar and attire to the deer.
regions.locationAlt: Ahvenanmaa location on the map of Finland

images.municipalityDescription: A silver seagull soars in the red upper section of the wavy shield, while a fish appears in the silver lower section. These symbols represent the municipality's location in the archipelago and highlight the significance of fishing to the area. It was designed by Matts Dreijer.

The coat of arms reflects Eckerö’s historical role in carrying mail across the Åland Sea to Stockholm, the capital of Sweden. The boat shown represents the type used for winter crossings. The blazon reads: 'In a silver field, a red cargo boat with a red square sail.' Designed by Matts Dreijer, the coat of arms was approved by the Eckerö municipal council on January 31, 1952, and officially sanctioned by the Åland Provincial Government on February 27 of the same year.

The wavy line in Finström's coat of arms symbolizes the Kyrkström stream, a small waterway thought to have inspired the name of parish. The oak tree represents the resilience of the people and the area has rich vegetation. The coat of arms is described as “in a red field, a golden oak above a wave-crowned silver bar.” Designed by Matts Dreijer, it was approved by the Finström municipal council on May 22, 1948. The Åland Provincial Government officially authorized its use on December 19,1951, and a revised description of the blazon was approved on October 8, 1969.

The design of the coat of arms reflects both the natural beauty of the archipelago and the name of municipality, which comes from the Swedish word fågel, meaning “bird.” The blazon describes the coat of arms as “in a blue field, three golden ducks flying diagonally upward, arranged in a 2 + 1 pattern.” It was designed by Matts Dreijer and A. W. Rancken, and approved by the Föglö municipal council on September 15, 1948. The Åland Provincial Government officially sanctioned it for use on October 31, 1951.

The design of the coat of arms reflects both the possible origin of the municipality's name—likely derived from get (the Swedish word for 'goat')—and the traditional goat farming practiced in this rugged, rocky archipelago. The coat of arms is blazoned as “in a blue field, a golden goat rearing.” Designed by Matts Dreijer, it was approved by the Geta municipal council on January 19, 1948, and officially sanctioned for use by the Åland Provincial Government on December 19, 1951.

The mountain symbol in the coat of arms refers to the Old Norse word hamar, meaning 'rock' or 'mountain', tying it to both the name of municipality and its rugged, rocky terrain. The Viking ship represents the local tradition that Hammarland was the first place sailors would reach when arriving from the west. The blazon of the coat of arms is described as “in a blue field, a golden Viking ship facing forward; below, in a golden base, a red triple-peaked mountain.” Designed by Matts Dreijer, the coat of arms was approved by the Hammarland municipal council in meetings held on February 14, 1948, and December 20, 1951. The Åland Provincial Government officially authorized its use on December 28, 1951.

The coat of arms design closely resembles the medieval seal of Åland, which has been preserved since 1326. Saint Olaf, the patron saint of both the entire archipelago and the Jomala Church (which dates back to the 13th century), is depicted in the design. The blazon reads: 'In a blue field, Saint Olaf seated on a throne, holding an orb and a battle-axe, all in gold.' The coat of arms was designed by Matts Dreijer and was approved by the Jomala municipal council on November 21, 1947. The Åland Provincial Government officially granted its use on February 27, 1952.

The design of the coat of arms refers to the primary livelihood of this outer archipelago municipality: fishing. The blazon of the coat of arms is described as 'in a blue field, a silver fish leaping, with red fins.' The coat of arms was designed by Matts Dreijer and was approved by the Kökar municipal council in its meeting on November 30, 1947. The Åland Provincial Government officially sanctioned its use on April 16, 1952.

The design of the coat of arms is inspired by the Lemböten Chapel, dedicated to Saint Olaf, which dates back to the 14th century. The blazon is described as 'in a black field, a golden chapel with two red windows; on the roof ridge, two golden crosses with arms ending in red triangles.' Designed by Matts Dreijer, the coat of arms was approved by the Lemland municipal council on December 22, 1947, and officially sanctioned for use by the Åland Provincial Government on December 28, 1951.

The coat of arms reflects the main livelihoods of the municipality: fishing and agriculture. The blazon is described as 'a golden sheaf in a blue field, with a silver fish on each side, both having red fins.' Designed by Matts Dreijer, the coat of arms was approved by the Lumparland municipal council on December 20, 1947, and officially sanctioned by the Åland Provincial Government on April 16, 1952.

Maarianhamina was founded in 1861 and named after Empress Maria Alexandrovna of Russia. Russian heraldist Bernhard von Köhne designed a coat of arms featuring the Russian eagle and a lion from Hesse. Another design by Governor-General Berg included the Empress's monogram and an anchor, but neither was approved. In 1878, a new design was created by Governor-General Adlerberg, featuring a golden M for Maria and a stag, which was approved in 1881. After Finland's independence, the old coat of arms faced criticism, leading to a design competition in 1948. Nils Byman won, and the new coat of arms was approved in 1949. The current design, based on Byman's work, was finalized in 1957. The coat of arms symbolizes main industry, seafaring, and parks, where lime trees are common. It features a blue shield with a gold anchor standing upright, and above it, three green lime tree leaves.

The coat of arms design reflects the ridge dividing Saltvik into West and East Saltvik. The lilies symbolize the area's historic stone church from the 13th century, dedicated to Saint Mary, whose heraldic symbol is the lily. The blazon describes it as 'a shield split by a lower ridge into red and gold; in the red field, two gold lilies side by side.' Matts Dreijer designed the coat of arms, and it was approved by the Saltvik municipal council on February 6, 1949. The Åland Provincial Government officially sanctioned it on April 9, 1952.

The coat of arms features a small medieval sailing boat, symbolizing the boats traditionally used for local sailing and small cargo transport in this archipelago municipality. The blazon is described as 'in a blue field, a boat above two wavy lines; all in gold, except for a red, triple-tongued flag at the top of the mast.' The coat of arms was designed by Matts Dreijer and approved by the Sottunga municipal council on December 30, 1947. The Åland Provincial Government officially sanctioned its use on March 27, 1952.

The coat of arms design symbolizes the two historical fortresses in the municipality: the medieval Kastelholm fortress and the Bomarsund fortress from the Russian period, now standing in ruins. The blazon is described as 'in a red field, a golden crenelated wall with a tower, topped by a golden pennant.' Matts Dreijer designed the coat of arms, which was approved by the Sund municipal council on December 27, 1947, and officially sanctioned by the Åland Provincial Government on December 19, 1951.

The design of the coat of arms, featuring a beacon or signal fire, references the municipality's name, which originates from the Old Norse word vardher, meaning watch, guard, or sentinel. In the past, signal fires were lit on Vårdö's Kasberg hill both to warn of danger and to guide sailors. The blazon is described as 'in a blue field, a silver cone with a gold-and-red flame.' The coat of arms was designed by Matts Dreijer and approved by the Vårdö municipal council on December 29, 1947. The Åland Provincial Government officially sanctioned its use on February 20, 1952.

consolidated.alt: Maarianhamina old municipality coat of arms

regions.name: Etelä-Karjala
regions.regionDescription: The revised heraldic description of South Karelia’s coat of arms from 2008 reads: 'On a shield split horizontally in red and black, a wavy silver bar appears with two clashing arms above it. The right arm, armored, wields a sword, while the left, covered in chain mail, holds a curved saber. All elements are silver, except for the golden hilts of the weapons and the joint rings on the armor.'The crossed arms and weapons are inspired by the historical coat of arms of Karelia, with colors traditional to the region. The wavy bar symbolizes Lake Saimaa and other regional waterways. This coat of arms was created by architect Tuula Taskula and approved by the South Karelia Regional Council on April 2, 1997. Before adopting this coat of arms, South Karelia used one designed by heraldist Olof Erikson in the 1980s, though it did not become widely recognized as a regional symbol. The historical coat of arms of Karelia represented South Karelia within the former Kymi and Southern Finland provinces, while the Province of Viipuri used Viipuri’s old city coat of arms. In 1989, heraldist Jukka Suvisaari designed a traditional house flag for South Karelia, featuring white, red, and yellow from the Karelian coat of arms—distinct from Karelia’s black-and-red house flag. On December 10, 2002, the South Karelia Regional Council also adopted a provincial flag that combines the coat of arms’ crossed arms with the black-and-red of the traditional Karelian flag.
regions.locationAlt: Etelä-Karjala location on the map of Finland

images.municipalityDescription: The design of the coat of arms refers to the power plants that began construction in the early 1920s at Tainionkoski and Imatrankoski. The blazon is described as 'in a red field, three upright, double-ended arrow-shaped silver lightning bolts tipped in gold.' The coat of arms was designed by Olof Eriksson and was approved by the Imatra town council on August 9, 1950. The Ministry of the Interior officially sanctioned its use on October 25 of the same year.

The coat of arms of Lappeenranta, blazoned as 'In a silver field, a wild man in natural colors with a club resting on the ground, standing on green soil and wearing green wreaths on his forehead and waist,' originates from the city’s 1652 seal. The wild man symbol references Lappeenranta's former name, Lappstrand, later reinterpreted in 1721 as Willmanstrand ('wild man’s shore') due to the old Swedish term lapp, meaning 'wild man'. After Sweden ceded Lappeenranta to Russia in 1743, the city adopted a modified coat of arms in 1788 based on this early seal, initially on a blue field. By 1892, George Granfelt's Finlands städers vapenbok depicted it on a silver field, a version that eventually became standard. Olof Eriksson's 1954 redesign introduced this silver field officially, along with a golden mural crown symbolizing Lappeenranta's fortress. The city’s former Nuijamies movie theater, now a cultural venue, takes its name from the wild man figure on the coat of arms.

The wavy division on the shield symbolizes the municipality’s location on the lake plains, while the potato flower highlights its well-known potato farming heritage. Designed by Gustaf von Numers, the coat of arms was officially adopted on May 16, 1962. The blazon is described as: 'A shield divided wavy in red and silver; in the red field, a silver potato flower with a golden pistil.'

The pine tree in the coat of arms symbolizes the pine forests of the Salpausselkä ridge and also honors President Svinhufvud, whose family estate was in Luumäki. The boar’s head is inspired by President Svinhufvud’s noble coat of arms, while the fortification represents the Taavetti Fortress. The blazon reads: 'In a field of gold, a black pine tree with a boar's head featuring red details to the right of the trunk and a five-pointed fortification to the left, all in black.' The coat of arms was designed by Gustaf von Numers and officially adopted on April 30, 1951.

The coat of arms of Parikkala represents the municipality formed in 2005 through the merger of Parikkala, Saari, and Uukuniemi. Its silver, red, and black colors follow the traditional heraldic palette of the Karelia region. The stepped crosses symbolize the unity of the merged municipalities and also reflect the shifting borders that have redefined the area through various peace treaties. The embattled black border emphasizes Parikkala’s historic role as a borderland between Finland, Sweden, and Russia. The blazon reads: 'On a silver shield, a black embattled border on the left side and three red stepped crosses arranged vertically.' Designed by Seppo Siitonen, the coat of arms was officially approved by the Parikkala municipal council on June 21, 2005.

The blue field represents the lake, while the spruce-topped pattern symbolizes the surrounding forests. The blazon states: 'In a blue field, a silver iron symbol with a silver chief topped with spruces.' Designed by Erkki Paakkinen, the coat of arms was approved by the Rautjärvi municipal council on March 21, 1961, and officially sanctioned by the Ministry of the Interior on June 26, 1961.

The wavy base typically symbolizes a body of water. The coat of arms was designed by Gustaf von Numers and was officially adopted on September 11, 1951. The blazon reads: 'In a blue field, a wavy silver base from which rise three common reeds, all in silver.'

The embattled design in Savitaipale’s coat of arms reflects the municipality’s historical role as a border parish between the Treaty of Turku in 1743 and a border adjustment in 1812. The hoof plow symbolizes an old plow type traditionally used in the region. The blazon reads: 'On a black field, a gold hoof plow with an embattled gold chief above.' Designed by Viljo Savikurki, the coat of arms was approved by the Savitaipale municipal council on January 2, 1953, and officially sanctioned by the Ministry of the Interior on March 3 of the same year.

The coat of arms of Taipalsaari reflects the municipality's location. The wavy base and tar steamer symbolize its position in the Saimaa archipelago and the freight vessels typical of the local waterways. The coat of arms was designed by Olof Eriksson and was officially adopted on May 20, 1959. The blazon reads: 'In a red field, above a wavy silver base, a silver tar steamer.'

regions.name: Etelä-Pohjanmaa
regions.regionDescription: The blazon reads: 'In a blue field, three silver ermines running in a row with black-tipped tails.' Created in 1997 by the Regional Council of South Ostrobothnia, the coat of arms was designed under the guidance of heraldic expert Touko Saari. The ermines, adapted from the historical Ostrobothnia coat of arms (which originally featured six), symbolize purity and wealth. Northern Ostrobothnia now uses the historical coat of arms without a crown, while Ostrobothnia retains ermines in its current emblem. Central Ostrobothnia, meanwhile, uses a marten-based design from an earlier version. The coat of arms also inspired the provincial flag, formally introduced on May 22, 2000. In June 2020, the regional council approved expanded flag use for official events and encouraged municipalities to display it. The colors of the coat of arms and flag are also found in South Ostrobothnia’s traditional house banner.
regions.locationAlt: Etelä-Pohjanmaa location on the map of Finland

images.municipalityDescription: The coat of arms honors the three tribes of frontiersmen who originally settled the region. One theory suggests that the name Ähtäri comes from the Estonian word ätsä, meaning 'marsh marigold,' reflected in the flowers depicted in the emblem. The blazon reads: 'In a blue field, two crossed silver arrows with a third arrow placed vertically above; in each upper corner, a golden five-petaled flower.' Designed by Ahti Hammar, the coat of arms was approved by the Ähtäri municipal council on June 29, 1951, and officially sanctioned by the Ministry of the Interior on October 25 of the same year.

The coat of arms is a 'canting' design that visually reflects the municipality’s name, with the base symbolizing the first part of the name and the wavy line representing the ending. Its colors also mirror those of the Ostrobothnia regional coat of arms. The blazon reads: 'In a blue field, a silver wavy base.' Created by Olof Eriksson, the coat of arms was approved by the Alajärvi municipal council on March 14, 1961, and officially sanctioned by the Ministry of the Interior on October 16 of the same year.

The coat of arms is considered 'canting' because of the fish with prominent fins and the wavy base, symbolizing the municipality's connection to water. Without the fish, it would be identical to Alajärvi's coat of arms. The blazon reads: 'In a blue field, two silver fish, back-to-back with red fins, rising from a silver wavy base.' Designed by Olof Eriksson, the coat of arms was approved by the Evijärvi municipal council on April 16, 1963, and officially sanctioned by the Ministry of the Interior on September 19 of the same year.

The coat of arms is based on the old parish seal and the 1590s peasant revolt. The blazon reads: 'In the silver upper field, a black bear's head facing forward. In the blue lower field, two crossed silver maces with a silver foot cross in the lower corners; a double-arched bowstring against a log, tied at the top.' The bear's head, taken from Ilmajoki's parish seal, symbolizes the municipality’s independence from Isojoki in 1532. The same bear also appeared on Isojoki's and Lapua's early seals. The maces and foot cross refer to the 1596–1597 peasant revolt and were originally linked to Jaakko Ilkka’s mark. However, later research confirmed the mark belonged to Yrjö Kontsa. Designed by heraldic artist Ahti Hammar, the coat of arms was approved by the Ilmajoki municipal council on July 5, 1950, and officially sanctioned by the Ministry of the Interior on October 25 of the same year.

The pole in the coat of arms represents both the river that flows through the municipality and the first letter of its name. The ear of grain symbolizes agriculture. The blazon reads: 'In a black field, a silver pole with a red ear of grain.' Designed by Pentti Vakkamaa, the coat of arms was approved by the Isojoki municipal council on October 26, 1965, and officially approved by the Ministry of the Interior on January 11, 1966.

The coat of arms of Isojoki is based on the seal of the old Isojoki parish, which features a bear standing against a tree trunk. This motif is faithfully reproduced in the coat of arms without significant alterations. Designed by Matti Visanti, the coat of arms was officially adopted on July 7, 1950. The blazon reads: 'On a gold shield, a black bear standing, with red tongue, teeth, and claws, holding a green fir root in its paws.'

The coat of arms subtly reflects the region’s meadow landscapes through a pattern reminiscent of scythe blades. Its blue and silver colors are inspired by the traditional coat of arms of the Ostrobothnia region. The blazon reads: 'A shield of blue and silver divided by a jagged line.' Designed by Ahti Hammar, the coat of arms was approved by the Karijoki municipal council on October 8, 1965, and officially sanctioned by the Ministry of the Interior on December 28 of that year.

The coat of arms of Kauhajoki was designed by heraldic artist Ahti Hammar and was officially adopted on October 17, 1952. In the blue upper field, two silver speaker’s gavels are crossed, symbolizing the Finnish Parliament’s stay in Kauhajoki during the Winter War from December 1, 1939, to February 12, 1940. The wavy line reflects the municipality’s name. In the silver lower field, a black bear’s head faces forward with a red tongue, referencing the old seal of Ilmajoki, the parish from which Kauhajoki originated. The blazon reads: 'In a shield divided by a wavy line, in the blue upper field, two crossed silver speaker’s gavels; in the silver lower field, a black bear’s head facing forward with a red tongue.'

The heraldic description of the coat of arms of Kauhava reads: 'In a blue field, a golden detached cross of Mantua, beneath which is a red belt with four lobes extending from edge to edge; the lobes and hearts in gold.' The Mantuan cross symbolizes bravery, while the four lobes represent the unity of the four merged municipalities. The coat of arms was designed by Reijo Helläkoski, based on the former arms of Kortesjärvi, and was adopted when Alahärmä, Kauhava, Kortesjärvi, and Ylihärmä merged to form the new city of Kauhava in 2009.

The pike in the coat of arms comes from the old parish seal, and the flames refer to a legend about a fire on Lake Kuortane. Two versions of this story have been gathered from local folklore. In one version, barrels of tar stored on the lake's western shore caught fire, and the burning tar flowed into the lake through ditches. In the other version, a hot copper vein rose from the lakebed, creating such dense steam upon contact with the water that it made the entire lake appear to be ablaze. The blazon reads: 'A silver-blue shield divided by a wavy line, with three red flames rising in the upper field and a silver pike swimming in the lower field.' Designed by Ahti Hammar, the coat of arms was approved by the Kuortane municipal council on July 5, 1957, and officially sanctioned by the Ministry of the Interior on October 17 of the same year.

Kurikka's coat of arms, designed by Kirsi-Maaria Markus from Jurva, was officially adopted in a ceremonial session of the Kurikka city council on December 31, 2008. The heraldic description reads: 'A shield divided by salmon-tail lines into blue and silver fields.' The original coat of arms, created by artist Ahti Hammar, had been in use since its approval in September 1951. When Jurva merged with Kurikka in 2009, a design competition was held to select a new coat of arms to represent the combined municipality.

The boat featured in the coat of arms is adapted from the old parish seal. The radiant golden base, originally interpreted as flames, symbolizes the historical belief that Lake Lappajärvi—after which the municipality is named—was formed by an ancient volcanic crater. The blazon reads: 'In a blue field, a silver boat with a square sail and rudder, above a golden base with a radiant pattern.' Designed by Ahti Hammar, the coat of arms was approved by the Lappajärvi municipal council on September 20, 1957, and officially sanctioned by the Ministry of the Interior on November 27 of that year.

The coat of arms is blazoned as follows: 'In a gold field, a black walking bear with red details, ridden by a man dressed in a blue tunic, trousers, and laced shoes, holding a black club raised for striking in his right hand.' The design of Lapua's coat of arms originates from the old parish seal. The earliest seal, dating back to 1599, featured only a forward-facing bear's head. This bear symbol was first used by the parent parish of Isojoki and was later adopted by Lapua and Ilmajoki when they became independent parishes. By the 18th century, after the original seal was lost during the Great Northern War, the image evolved to depict a man riding a bear and holding a club, a motif that became synonymous with Lapua and was also used in the seal of the Lapua district. Heraldic artist Gustaf von Numers designed the current coat of arms. It was approved by the Lapua municipal council on September 25, 1950, and officially sanctioned by the Ministry of the Interior on December 11 of that year.

The coat of arms, designed by heraldic artist Olof Eriksson, was officially adopted on May 16, 1951. The blazon describes it as: 'In a silver field, a blue wall with battlements spanning edge to edge, with a wavy base.' During the 2009 municipal mergers, a design competition was organized to create a new coat of arms for the enlarged city of Seinäjoki. However, none of the new designs were approved. Kari Hokkanen proposed retaining the original coat of arms, with the addition of a Cross of Liberty. Ultimately, the city council selected the original design, as proposed by the city board

The coat of arms references the parish’s old name, Kuninkaanjoki (King’s River), which also names a village in Soini. This name is believed to mean “border river,” though a local legend suggests it originated when King Gustav Vasa paused by the river for a drink. The blazon reads: 'In a red field, a wavy golden beam beneath a golden crown.' Designed by Kaj Kajander, the coat of arms was approved by the Soini municipal council on February 14, 1962, and officially sanctioned by the Ministry of the Interior on August 29 of the same year.

The blazon reads: 'In a blue field, two silver flails crossed.' The coat of arms was designed by Ahti Hammar and approved by the Teuva municipal council on December 30, 1952. It was officially sanctioned by the Ministry of the Interior on April 20, 1953.

The coat of arms of Alavus is the symbol of the city of Alavus. Its design refers to the ancient Tohninmäki cross-shaped ruin site. The coat of arms was originally approved as the seal of the municipality of Töysä on February 18, 1959. The blazon reads: 'In a blue field, a triangular point from which rises a cross with arched arms; both in silver.' The coat of arms was designed by Gustaf von Numers and was approved by the Töysä municipal council on December 23, 1958. It was officially sanctioned by the Ministry of the Interior on February 18, 1959.

The ski motif in the coat of arms represents the parish's tradition of ski masters, with the skis arranged to form the initial letter of the town's name. The flame symbolizes the ancient practice of slash-and-burn farming in the wilderness. The blazon reads: 'In a blue field, two silver skis crossed back-to-back like a knee brace, with a golden flame between them.' The coat of arms was designed by Olof Eriksson and approved by the Vimpeli municipal council on June 30, 1960. It was officially granted by the Ministry of the Interior on November 22 of the same year.

regions.name: Etelä-Savo
regions.regionDescription: The heraldic blazon reads: 'In a black field, a handbow set in tension, all in gold, except for the bowstring, arrowhead, and fletched tail, which are silver.' The design is a variation of the Savonia region's historical coat of arms, used in its crownless form by North Savonia. Early versions of Savonia's coat of arms showed the bow in the same orientation as South Savonia's, which is considered a heraldic exception. The Savonian bow appears in the coats of arms of Mikkeli and Savonlinna and in the traditional Savonian host banner.
regions.locationAlt: Etelä-Savo location on the map of Finland

images.municipalityDescription: In 1858, churchgoers from Enonkoski were traveling to Kerimäki by boat for a service. On their way back, the boat capsized in strong winds, tragically drowning eight villagers. As a result, Enonkoski became its own parish, and the first church was built the following year. To honor this tragedy, the coat of arms includes silver oars, representing the boating accident. The four clovers on the shield symbolize agriculture, reflecting the area's farming roots. The coat of arms, designed by Olof Eriksson based on an earlier version, was officially adopted on November 23, 1954. The blazon reads: 'In a black field, two silver oars crossed in saltire, with four golden clovers as supporters.'

The coat of arms of Hirvensalmi represents the municipality and is a canting coat of arms, derived from the name 'Hirvensalmi' (meaning 'moose strait'). The blazon reads: 'In a gold field, a black walking moose with red hooves.' The coat of arms was designed by Gustaf von Numers and was approved by the Hirvensalmi municipal council on December 22, 1952. It was officially confirmed by the Ministry of the Interior on April 20, 1953.

The cross symbolizes the now-destroyed medieval St. Cross Church, which once stood in the parish. The cloverleaf represents agriculture. The decorative patterns used in the coat of arms are examples of damask work, which was used to fill the empty spaces in the shield, but they are not part of the official heraldic description. The blazon reads: 'In a black field, a cross, with a cloverleaf in the upper right corner, all in gold.' The coat of arms was designed by Tapio Vallioja and was approved by the Juva municipal council on June 19, 1952. The Ministry of the Interior officially confirmed it on August 23 of the same year.

The coat of arms symbolizes the women of the parish, renowned for their expertise in weaving patterned fabrics. It also reflects the municipality’s name, as 'kangas' is a homonym meaning 'fabric' or 'cloth.' The blazon reads: 'In a black field, a golden spinning wheel with a silver thread.' Designed by Olof Eriksson, the coat of arms was approved by the Kangasniemi municipal council on January 29, 1953, and officially confirmed by the Ministry of the Interior on June 12 of the same year.

The coat of arms of Mäntyharju is a canting coat of arms directly referring to the name of the municipality, which can be translated to English as 'Pine Ridge.' The coat of arms was designed by Ahti Hammar and was officially adopted on April 20, 1953. The blazon reads: 'In a black field, two pine trees growing from golden base arcs; all in gold.'

The coat of arms of Mikkeli, featuring the Savonian bow and marshal's batons, is the city's official emblem. It also includes the Cross of Liberty and is topped with a Swedish-style count's crown. Designed by Gunnar Clément and redrawn by Eero Jokilehto, the design was confirmed in 1943. Created to honor Mikkeli's role as the Finnish Army’s General Headquarters during the Winter War, Continuation War, and Lapland War, the coat of arms was initially used without the honor decoration. In December 1944, Mikkeli was awarded the 4th Class Cross of Liberty with swords for its military service, and the city's coat of arms became the emblem of the honor decoration.

The coat of arms of Pertunmaa is the official emblem of the municipality, and its design is inspired by ancient slash-and-burn farming. The blazon reads: 'In a red field, a golden flame with a black ear of grain.' The coat of arms was designed by Tapio Vallioja, and it was approved by the Pertunmaa municipal council on April 14, 1965. The Ministry of the Interior officially confirmed it on July 1 of the same year.

The coat of arms symbolizes ancient hunting expeditions in the wilderness. The blazon reads: 'In a black field, three golden axes with silver feathers, pointed downward.' Designed by Ahti Hammar, it was first approved as the coat of arms for Pieksämäki Rural Municipality on April 18, 1951, and officially confirmed by the Ministry of the Interior on September 11, 1951. After the 2004 merger of Jäppilä, Virtasalmi, and Pieksämäki Rural Municipality, it became the emblem of Pieksänmaa, and later the coat of arms for Pieksämäki after the 2007 merger with the city. Pieksämäki's earlier coat of arms, also by Hammar, featured 'a golden saltire and a clover cross in a black field' and was approved by the town council on September 20, 1951. The old coat of arms symbolized the area's key role as a railway junction and its spiritual heritage.

The coat of arms refers to the history of the locality: following the Treaty of Turku in 1743, Puumala became a border parish, and due to its strategic location, the narrow Puumalansalmi has been the site of several battles dating back to the 1500s. The blazon reads: 'In a black shield, three silver wolf’s teeth rising from the base of the shield, with black, flame-like grenades.' The coat of arms was designed by Tapio Vallioja, and it was approved by the Puumala municipal council on September 24, 1962. The Ministry of the Interior officially confirmed it on April 18, 1963.

The coat of arms of Rantasalmi is the emblem of the municipality, inspired by its name, making it a canting coat of arms. The name 'Rantasalmi' can be translated to 'Shore Strait' in English, and the wavy bar symbolizes the strait between two shores. The blazon reads: 'In a gold field, a black wavy bar.' The coat of arms was designed by Ahti Hammar and was approved by the Rantasalmi municipal council on June 16, 1958. The Ministry of the Interior officially confirmed it on October 1 of the same year.

The coat of arms of Savonlinna is inspired by symbols of regional history, particularly the bow from the historical Savonia coat of arms and the iconic Olavinlinna Castle. The bow and arrow were depicted in the city’s seal as early as the 1600s, while the castle, strategically located on Kyrönsalmi island, became part of the coat of arms when it was formally established in 1788. The blazon describes: 'In a blue field, a golden three-towered castle above a silver wavy bar; below, in a black base, an upright golden bow with silver bowstring, arrowhead, and fletching.' The current design was refined by the University of Industrial Arts Helsinki and officially adopted on April 4, 1989, highlighting the castle above a wavy bar that separates the base from the main field.

The bridge in the coat of arms represents the old road in Savonlinna that crosses waterways at the village center. The pine cones symbolize the surrounding forests and the forestry industry. The coat of arms was designed by Gustaf von Numers and was officially adopted on September 23, 1953. The blazon reads: 'In a black field, a silver single-arched stone bridge extending from edge to edge, accompanied by golden pine cones, three above and one below, with stems pointing upward.'

regions.name: Kainuu
regions.regionDescription: The coat of arms of Kainuu is described heraldically as: 'In a gold field, a green fess embattled at the top and wavy at the bottom.' Designed by heraldist Olof Eriksson in 1978 for the Kainuu Regional Council, it was officially adopted as the regional coat of arms during the 1997 provincial reform. The design reflects Kainuu's natural features: the embattled line symbolizes the region's extensive forests, while the wavy line represents its waterways, both of which have played a significant role in Kainuu's history.
regions.locationAlt: Kainuu location on the map of Finland

images.municipalityDescription: The coat of arms highlights the historical significance of tar production, once a vital livelihood in the parish's extensive forests. The wavy pale represents the latter part of the municipality's name, salmi (meaning 'strait'). The blazon states: 'In a silver field, a blue wavy pale charged with a golden tar barrel.' Designed by Aarno Liuksiala, the coat of arms was approved by the Hyrynsalmi municipal council on May 24, 1967, and March 27, 1968, before being officially confirmed by the Ministry of the Interior on June 8, 1968.

The coat of arms of Kajaani, the city's official emblem, is a modernized version of an earlier design rooted in 17th- and 18th-century seals. Its imagery reflects the city's historical origins, centered around Kajaani Castle, a border fortress established in the early 1600s on an island in the Ämmänkoski rapids. The blazon reads: 'In a blue field, a golden two-towered castle with red window and door openings, rising from a silver wavy base.'

The coat of arms of Kuhmo, the official emblem of the city, symbolizes the wilderness nature of the region. The blazon reads: 'In a black field, three golden spruce trees arranged 2 + 1.' The coat of arms was designed by Olof Eriksson and was approved by the Kuhmo municipal council on December 21, 1951. The Ministry of the Interior officially confirmed it on March 1, 1952.

The coat of arms is inspired by tar production and trade, which were vital to the region, especially in the 19th century, although tar had been produced in Paltamo as early as the 17th century. The blazon reads: 'In a gold field, three black tar boats with barrels arranged horizontally one above the other.' The coat of arms was designed by Gustaf von Numers and was approved by the Paltamo municipal council on March 20, 1953. The Ministry of the Interior officially confirmed it on September 19 of the same year.

The coat of arms of Puolanka features a spruce crown symbolizing forestry and cowbells representing cattle herding and the traditional practice of forest grazing. The blazon reads: 'In a black field, three golden cowbells arranged 2:1, beneath a golden chief embattled to resemble spruce treetops.' Designed by Aake Kaarnama, the coat of arms was approved by the Puolanka municipal council on June 8, 1962, and officially confirmed by the Ministry of the Interior on August 29 of the same year.

The blazon reads: 'In a blue field, a wavy silver base, above which is a silver coniferous cross.' The coat of arms was designed by Aarno Liuksiala, and was approved by the Ristijärvi municipal council on March 23 and May 25, 1959. The Ministry of the Interior officially confirmed it on November 23 of the same year.

The coat of arms represents Vuokatti, a place in the center of the parish surrounded by waterways. The blazon reads: 'In a silver field, a blue log with an arched top.' Designed by Toivo Vuorela, the coat of arms was approved by the Sotkamo municipal council on January 2, 1962, and officially confirmed by the Ministry of the Interior on June 9 of the same year.

The flagpoles on the coat of arms represent the traditional torch fires (pärevalkeat) once used in the area. Their number reflects the four ancestral farms mentioned in 1604, which were located near the eastern border, first defined in the Treaty of Täyssinä. The blazon reads: 'In a black field, four silver flagpoles arranged 1+2+1, with a golden flame rising from each.' The coat of arms was designed by Gustaf von Numers and approved by the Suomussalmi municipal council on July 11, 1966. The Ministry of the Interior officially confirmed it on September 21 of the same year.

regions.name: Kanta-Häme
regions.regionDescription: The coat of arms of Häme features a golden lynx, symbolizing the area's abundant lynx population and the historical importance of hunting. The stars and roses were added to fill empty spaces, following heraldic tradition. The design was confirmed by the Ministry of the Interior in 1963, based on a model by heraldist Ahti Hammar. Häme’s first known symbol dates back to 1326, and the province's official arms were granted in 1560 by King Gustav Vasa. The lynx appears in the arms of several municipalities and regional emblems.
regions.locationAlt: Kanta-Häme location on the map of Finland

images.municipalityDescription: The coat of arms is based on an emblem established by a presidential decree in 1947, before the municipal law was enacted. It features a waterwheel, symbolizing the old mills by the rapids, around which the area's industrial development began. The blazon reads: 'In a blue field, a silver waterwheel.' Designed by Olof Eriksson, the coat of arms was approved by the Forssa Town Council on June 18, 1962, and officially confirmed by the Ministry of the Interior on August 29, 1962.

The coat of arms, based on a 17th-century city seal, represents Hämeen Castle near which the city was founded in 1639. It features a silver wall with two towers and a building between them, symbolizing the castle. Above the castle are golden sun faces. The design, created by Gustaf von Numers in 1956, replaced an earlier version. The main change was the color scheme: the castle was originally red, but in the new design, the colors were reversed, with the silver castle on a red shield, and the wavy bottom representing Lake Vanajavesi.

The coat of arms of Hattula features the medieval Church of the Holy Cross and the Mierola Bridge, built in 1919, located about one and a half kilometers from the church. The design was created by Erkki Karttunen and was confirmed on March 12, 1957. The blazon reads: 'In a red field, a single-arched bridge extending to the edges, with a Greek cross above it; both in gold.'

The diagonal cross on the coat of arms represents the municipality's historical location at the crossroads of major roads, while the star refers to Finland's first national school, Eskon School, founded in 1856 by General Johan Reinhold Munck. The star is derived from his family's coat of arms. The blazon reads: 'In a red field, a diagonal cross with a star at the point of intersection, all in silver.' The coat of arms was designed by Olof Eriksson and was approved by the Hausjärvi municipal council on December 9, 1952. The Ministry of the Interior officially confirmed it on April 20, 1953.

The coat of arms represents the historical manor houses and their cottagers. The blazon reads: 'In a gold field, a black food bell hanging from a canopy.' The original design was created by Risto Sulonen, with Olof Eriksson later refining it into the final version. The Humppila municipal council approved the coat of arms on June 1, 1957, and the Ministry of the Interior officially confirmed it on September 25 of the same year.

The coat of arms of Janakkala is inspired by the municipality's location. The lynx, the regional animal of Kanta-Häme, represents Janakkala's position in the heart of Häme. The embattled base refers to the Hakoisten hillfort, while the cross surrounded by two arrows above it symbolizes the battles of the Crusades. The coat of arms was designed by Onni Oja and was officially confirmed on February 23, 1952. The blazon reads: 'In a red field, a golden lynx's head facing forward, with a blue tongue and black ear tufts; above, an embattled golden crown with a Mantova cross, with arrows pointing towards it on either side; all in black.'

The ear of grain in the coat of arms symbolizes the role of the Jokioinen estate in the development of Finnish agriculture, while the anvil represents the Jokioinen ironworks. The blazon reads: 'In a red field, a wavy log with two crossed ears of wheat above and an anvil below; all in gold.' The coat of arms was designed by Gustaf von Numers and was approved by the Jokioinen municipal council on July 30, 1951. The Ministry of the Interior officially confirmed it on September 21 of the same year.

The coat of arms, featuring a symbol of iron embedded in a wavy-edged shield, refers to the historical extraction of lake ore. The blazon reads: 'A shield, wavy-cut in red and silver, with an alternating-colored iron mark.' The coat of arms was designed by Olof Eriksson and was approved by the Loppi municipal council on June 27 and September 17, 1952. The Ministry of the Interior officially confirmed it on September 23 of the same year.

The motif of the coat of arms, with the sheaf, indirectly refers to the municipality's name, while the flames symbolize industry, particularly the important glass factory at the time. The divided belt on the shield can be interpreted as a reference to the railway, which was essential for the development of the local community. The blazon reads: 'A shield divided by a golden belt, with seven upward-pointing red flames in the silver upper field and a golden sheaf in the red lower field.' The coat of arms was designed by Arttu Brummer, and the emblem for the town of Riihimäki was confirmed by President J. K. Paasikivi through a decree on August 15, 1947.

The oak branches with leaves in the coat of arms are a direct reference to the town's name, making the emblem symbolic of the place. The coat of arms was designed by Gustaf von Numers and was officially confirmed on December 29, 1953. The blazon reads: 'In a red field, three oak leaves with stems converging into a forked cross, with an acorn sprouting from the junction of the stems on each side; all in silver.'

The coat of arms depicts the bell tower of the old Perttula chapel, demolished in 1901, with the ear of grain symbolizing local agriculture. Designed by Aukusti Tuhka and confirmed on June 27, 1949, the blazon reads: 'In a split shield, a silver bell tower in the left blue field, and a red ear of grain in the right silver field.' Ypäjä’s coat of arms was one of the first in Finnish-speaking rural municipalities, inspired by professor Esko Aaltonen in the late 1940s. Tuhka also designed unofficial emblems for several other municipalities, but only Ypäjä’s was officially confirmed.

regions.name: Keski-Pohjanmaa
regions.regionDescription: The coat of arms of Central Ostrobothnia features a silver marten with golden claws and tongue, looking backward, on a blue field. It is accompanied by three silver nail crosses above and two below. Designed by heraldist Gustaf von Numers in 1950, it became the region’s official emblem in 1997. The marten originates from the 1562 coat of arms of historical Ostrobothnia, while the nail crosses symbolize the region’s five original parishes and its skilled craftsmanship. The traditional colors—blue, silver, and gold—also appear in the regional pennant (designed in 1979) and the regional flag adopted in 2000. Elements from the coat of arms, such as the marten and nail crosses, have also been used in the arms of Kaarlela (now part of Kokkola), Kaustinen, and Perho.
regions.locationAlt: Keski-Pohjanmaa location on the map of Finland

images.municipalityDescription: The coat of arms of Halsua reflects the tradition of folk music that emerged in the Perhonjoki Valley during the 19th century. The success of Kreeta Haapasalo, a musician who moved to the area, inspired other local players to tour and perform in Southern and Central Finland. Designed by Kaj Kajander based on an earlier version, the coat of arms was officially adopted on March 12, 1969. Its blazon reads: ‘In a red field, two silver round-based kanteles placed opposite each other, with blue strings.’

In addition to spur stars, the design references the hammer of a shaman’s drum, which is called a kannus. The coat of arms, designed by Gustaf von Numers based on an earlier version, was officially adopted on September 27, 1950. Its blazon reads: ‘In a blue field, a vertical silver shaman's drum hammer (kannus), flanked on either side by a six-pointed silver spur star.’

The coat of arms highlights the area's rich folk music tradition with a violin and honors the Kuorikoski family of church builders with nail crosses. Over four generations, this family constructed many churches and gained nationwide recognition. Designed by Ilmari Wirkkala based on an earlier version, the coat of arms was officially adopted on October 25, 1950. The description reads: ‘In a blue field scattered with golden nail crosses, a golden violin set crosswise.’

The coat of arms of Kokkola originates from the city seal granted in 1620 at the time of its founding. The design reflects the importance of tar burning and the tar trade, which were central to the city’s history from its establishment through the 19th century. The current version, created by Olof Eriksson and Into I. Suominen, is based on the original design and was officially adopted on December 17, 1956. The blazon describes it as: ‘In a gold field, a black tar barrel lying on its side, with red flames emerging from the bung hole and both ends.’ Kokkola's coat of arms is notably similar to that of Uusikaarlepyy, differing mainly in the barrel’s orientation and the color scheme.

The coat of arms reflects the area's historical wilderness nature. The blazon reads: ‘In a silver field, a blue capercaillie tail.’ Designed by Gustaf von Numers, the coat of arms was approved by the Lestijärvi Municipal Council on September 29, 1966, and officially confirmed by the Ministry of the Interior on January 19, 1967.

The name Perho means ‘butterfly’ in Finnish, which is represented by the golden butterfly in the design. The nail cross above the butterfly references Johan Ludvig Runeberg's poem ‘Hauta Perhossa’ (‘Grave in Perho’). Designed by Gustaf von Numers, the coat of arms was officially confirmed on March 6, 1953. The blazon reads: ‘In a black field, a golden butterfly, with a silver nail cross above it.’

The old dialect word ‘totto’ means a watch fire, and the coat of arms depicts a chain of watch fires. The coat of arms was designed by Gustaf von Numers and was officially confirmed on May 28, 1952. The blazon reads: ‘In a silver field, a black bow with a branch-like upper part; from each branch rises a red flame.’

The coat of arms of Veteli is inspired by the local folk musician Kreeta Haapasalo. It depicts her kantele (a traditional Finnish stringed instrument). The coat of arms was designed by Gustaf von Numers, based on the previous design, and was officially confirmed on April 21, 1952. The blazon reads: ‘In a silver field, a blue pole with a seven-string golden kantele; the strings are red.’

regions.name: Keski-Suomi
regions.regionDescription: The heraldic description of the coat of arms is: ‘In a silver field, a black, red-breasted capercaillie.’ Designed by herald Ahto Numminen in 1951 for the Central Finland Regional Council, it became the official emblem of the region following the administrative reform of 1997. From 1962 to 1997, it was part of the coat of arms of Central Finland County. The colors—black, silver, and red—are taken from the emblem of the Central Finland student association at the University of Helsinki, established in 1932. These colors are also used in the traditional Central Finland regional flag. In 1985, the capercaillie was chosen as Central Finland's regional bird.
regions.locationAlt: Keski-Suomi location on the map of Finland

images.municipalityDescription: The coat of arms of Äänekoski represents the city and was designed by Olof Eriksson. The blazon reads: ‘In a blue field, three flying silver cranes arranged in the shape of a right-pointing arrow.’ It was initially granted as the municipal coat of arms of the town of Suolahti on February 12, 1952. The design is inspired by the marshy bay that gave the area its name, which serves as a resting place for cranes during migration. In 2007, Äänekoski adopted this coat of arms following the merger of the municipalities of Äänekoski, Suolahti, and Sumiaiset. The original coat of arms of the town of Äänekoski, granted on October 14, 1954, was designed by Gustaf von Numers. Its blazon was: ‘In a black field, a wavy silver bar with three red horns and straps.’ This design, a ‘speaking’ coat of arms, was inspired by the town's name, with the wavy bar symbolizing the rapids and the horns representing sound.

The coat of arms features a tool placed on a wave-cornered log, symbolizing a bay. The blazon reads: ‘In a black field, a wave-cornered silver log, with a red tool resting on it.’ Designed by Ahti Hammar, the coat of arms was approved by the Hankasalmi municipal council on June 25, 1957, and officially confirmed by the Ministry of the Interior on October 3 of the same year.

The coat of arms of Jämsä was designed by Gustaf von Numers. The blazon is described as: ‘In a red field, a hedgehog iron, surrounded by a chain; both in silver.’ It was first granted as the municipal coat of arms for Jämsänkoski on April 3, 1954. The chain motif connects the arms of Jämsä with its daughter municipalities, Jämsänkoski and Koskenpää. The hedgehog iron, historically used to adjust the spacing between millstones, symbolizes the area's old water mills and its early industrial development. When Jämsä and Jämsänkoski merged in 2009, the latter's coat of arms was adopted as the official emblem of the city.

The coat of arms of Joutsa draws its inspiration from the region's ancient wilderness, represented by the bow and arrow. The bow also directly references the name ‘Joutsa’. Designed by Gustaf von Numers, the coat of arms was officially approved on November 10, 1955. The blazon reads: ‘In a red field, a six-cornered base and a log bow, with an arrow above, the string, arrowhead, and feathers in gold, and the rest in silver.’

The coat of arms of Jyväskylä is the official symbol of the city, representing trade and the region's inland waterway transportation. The current design was created by Jussi Jäppinen. The blazon reads: ‘A divided shield, with a silver caduceus on a blue field in the upper part, and in the lower part, on a silver field, the bow of a freshwater boat in natural colors, viewed from the front, with three blue wavy lines beneath it.’

The coat of arms of Kannonkoski is the official emblem of the municipality, and its design is closely related to the name of the area. It reflects the geographical features of the area, likely referring to a natural rapids or stream that was historically significant to the municipality. The blazon reads: ‘In a red field, a wave-shaped base with a stump above it; both in silver.’ The coat of arms was designed by Olof Eriksson and was approved by the Kannonkoski Municipal Council on July 9, 1959. The Ministry of the Interior confirmed its use on September 28 of the same year.

The coat of arms reflects Karstula's historical role as the ‘Gateway to Ostrobothnia,’ as the inland routes to Ostrobothnia have passed through Karstula in the past and continue to do so today. The blazon reads: ‘In a red field, a silver lock plate in the shape of an anchor cross, with a keyhole in the center.’ Designed by Ahti Hammar, the coat of arms was approved by the Karstula Municipal Council on March 9, 1953, and was officially adopted by the Ministry of the Interior on July 16 of the same year.

The coat of arms of the city of Keuruu is inspired by the region's agricultural heritage and the tradition of church boat journeys to the local church. Designed by Olof Eriksson, the coat of arms was approved on December 30, 1952. The blazon reads: ‘In a red field, two silver ropes crossed, with a silver cradle above, containing a black church boat.’

The design of the coat of arms reflects the traditional practice of slash-and-burn farming, represented through its shape, crown, and color choices. The blazon reads: ‘In a silver field, three branch-crowned, black-and-red sawteeth.’ Created by Ahti Hammar, the coat of arms was approved by the Kinnula municipal council on September 17, 1958, and officially adopted by the Ministry of the Interior on January 2, 1959.

The coat of arms of Kivijärvi is based on a local legend associated with the town's church. According to the story, the construction of the first church stalled as all work completed during the day was mysteriously destroyed overnight. To resolve this, it was decided to place a rooster on a log in the middle of the lake, and where the rooster landed, the church would be built. The coat of arms was designed by Gustaf von Numers and officially adopted on April 18, 1963. The blazon reads: ‘In a silver field, a red, wave-crowned log, with a black rooster, its legs red, standing on it.’

The coat of arms symbolizes the importance of forestry to the municipality of Konnevesi. The blazon is described as: ‘In a red field, silver timber scissors.’ The timber scissors represent the region's historical connection to forestry, particularly the cutting and processing of timber, which has played a significant role in the local economy and culture. The coat of arms was designed by heraldist Gustaf von Numers, and it was adopted by the Konnevesi municipal council on April 23, 1964. The Ministry of the Interior officially granted approval for its use on August 21 of the same year.

The coat of arms of Kyyjärvi is the official symbol of the municipality, with elements that reflect local features and history. The wavy bordure and the snake motif represent key aspects of the region's identity. The blazon reads: ‘In a blue field, a wavy left bordure and a serpentine snake; all in silver.’ The wavy bordure symbolizes water or the lakes that are significant to the area, while the snake likely represents the natural environment, referencing the area's wildlife. The silver color emphasizes clarity and purity, with both elements combining to create a strong, recognizable emblem for the municipality. The coat of arms was designed by Kaj Kajander, and it was approved by the Kyyjärvi municipal council on May 9, 1969. The Ministry of the Interior officially confirmed its use on July 21 of the same year.

The coat of arms of Laukaa is the official symbol of the municipality. Its design reflects the area's abundant coniferous forests and its central location in Finland. The blazon reads: ‘In a silver field, a red heart from which grows a three-pronged green conifer branch.’ The heart represents the central position of Laukaa, while the conifer branch symbolizes the region's rich forests. The coat of arms was designed by Olof Eriksson and was approved by the Laukaa municipal council on June 6, 1955. The Ministry of the Interior officially confirmed its use on September 5 of the same year.

The coat of arms of Luhanka is inspired by the municipality's history. The badger represents the area's historical significance in fur trapping, while the three crosses symbolize the three churches that once stood in the region. The blazon is described as: ‘In a green field, a silver badger with golden claws, walking, and accompanied by three golden, nailed, arch-shaped crosses, two above and one below.’ Designed by Gustaf von Numers, the coat of arms was officially adopted on September 1, 1965.

The coat of arms of Multia is the official symbol of the municipality, inspired by the local nickname ‘Multian keltiäiset’, which refers to ants. ‘Keltiäinen’ is a dialectal word for an ant, and this term influenced the choice of color for the ant in the coat of arms. The blazon is: ‘In a black field, a golden ant.’ Designed by Ahti Hammar, the coat of arms was officially adopted on November 26, 1963.

The coat of arms of Muurame reflects the municipality's name through the use of the crowberry plant. The blazon reads: ‘In a red field, a silver crowberry with a golden berry.’ The crowberry (Empetrum nigrum) not only ties the coat of arms to nature but also serves as a visual pun on the name ‘Muurame,’ as the Finnish word for crowberry (variksenmarja) indirectly connects to the region's name through cultural and linguistic associations. The blazon is: ‘In a red field, a silver crowberry with a golden berry.’ The coat of arms was designed by Ahti Hammar and was officially adopted on February 6, 1960.

The coat of arms of Petäjävesi reflects the municipality's name, meaning ‘Pine Water,’ and its natural features. The black pine symbolizes the region's dense forests and its forestry heritage. The red wavy base represents water, referencing the area's abundant lakes and waterways. The blazon is: ‘In a silver field, above a red wavy base, a black Scots pine.’ The coat of arms was designed by Olof Eriksson and officially adopted on February 12, 1963.

The division of the shield in the coat of arms represents both the interplay between water and land in the region and its location at the crossroads of the historical provinces of Häme, Ostrobothnia, and Savo. The silver arrowheads evoke the traditions of ancient hunters who roamed the area. The blazon is: ‘Quartered in silver and black, in the second and third fields, silver arrowheads.’ Designed by Olof Eriksson, the coat of arms was approved by the Pihtipudas municipal council on June 28, 1961, and officially adopted by the Ministry of the Interior on October 16 of the same year.

The coat of arms of Saarijärvi reflects the municipality's name and geography, symbolizing its lakes and forested islands. The silver field represents the lakes, while the saw-toothed beams evoke the wooded islands that break the waters. The colors—silver, black, and red—are traditional heraldic colors of the Central Finland region. The blazon is: ‘In a silver field, three saw-toothed beams at the top, the central one red and the outer ones black.’ Designed by Ahti Hammar, the coat of arms was approved by the Saarijärvi municipal council on July 12, 1954, and officially adopted by the Ministry of the Interior on September 14, 1954.

The coat of arms of Toivakka draws its inspiration from the municipality's name. The sower depicted in the design symbolizes agriculture as well as hope for the future. Additionally, the image of the sowing basket (vakka) creates a connection to the name ‘Toivakka,’ making the coat of arms both meaningful and symbolic. Its blazon reads: ‘In a green field, a sower in silver garments; the sowing basket with straps and footwear in gold.’ The coat of arms was designed by Gustaf von Numers and officially adopted on April 23, 1957.

The coat of arms of Uurainen represents the municipality’s identity, with its shield division and colors reflecting the hilly terrain of North Häme. The ski pole with a basket symbolizes both historical modes of transportation and Uurainen's success in competitive skiing. The blazon reads: ‘In a green field, a golden bow-shaped tip with a green ski pole basket.’ Designed by Tapio Vallioja, the coat of arms was approved by the Uurainen municipal council on May 4 and December 22, 1964, and was officially granted for use by the Ministry of the Interior on February 12, 1965.

The coat of arms symbolizes the historical importance of inland fishing in the region. The blazon reads: ‘In a red field, seven fully silver swimming vendace arranged in a pattern of 1+2+1+2+1.’ Designed by Olof Eriksson, the coat of arms was approved by the Viitasaari municipal council on April 7, 1952, and officially granted for use by the Ministry of the Interior on August 5 of the same year.

regions.name: Kymenlaakso
regions.regionDescription: The coat of arms of Kymenlaakso represents the region and features a rising silver salmon with gold fins and tail on a divided shield. The lower section of the shield depicts a blue net. Designed by herald Gustaf von Numers in 1951 for the Kymenlaakso Regional Council, the design references the Kymijoki River, a historic and vital salmon river. The colors of blue and silver were chosen to highlight the region’s natural heritage and its connection to the coastal municipalities historically considered part of Uusimaa. The coat of arms was adopted in 1997 after the regional administrative reform and had previously been part of the Kymen Province's heraldry from 1962 to 1997.
regions.locationAlt: Kymenlaakso location on the map of Finland

images.municipalityDescription: The original coat of arms was based on a seal granted to the town of Vehkalahti in 1660. The royal crown represents King Frederick I of Sweden. After the town of Vehkalahti was destroyed during the Great Northern War, Hamina was established as a royal town (Fredrikshamn) in its place, under the king's name. Hamina’s coat of arms is the only municipal coat of arms in Finland that incorporates purple. The blazon reads: ‘In a blue field, a silver, wavy timber log with a golden boat floating on it, above which is a golden royal crown with purple lining.’ The coat of arms of Hamina was designed by Gustaf von Numers, drawing inspiration from the city's original arms.

The city of Kotka was founded in 1879, and its first coat of arms was confirmed in 1881. However, in 1954, the city council had to redesign the old coat of arms because it no longer met heraldic standards. Blazon: ‘In a blue field, a golden natural eagle with wings raised, standing on a crossed anchor and caduceus, both in silver.’ The new coat of arms was designed by Olof Eriksson in 1957, and he retained the city's main emblem, the eagle, which references the city's name. In the current coat of arms, the anchor symbolizes Kotka’s significance as a port city, and the caduceus (Mercury's staff) represents trade, industry, and transportation.

The blazon reads: ‘On a black shield, a silver wavy base and a golden, lily-tipped, six-part rosette.’ The six segments of the rosette symbolize the union of the six municipalities(Anjalankoski, Elimäki, Jaalan, Kuusankoski, Valkeala and Kotka), while the lilies at the ends of each part represent the yellow iris, the emblematic plant of the Kymenlaakso region. The colors black and silver are the traditional heraldic colors of the region. The wavy base represents the Kymi River that flows through the city. The coat of arms was designed by Tapani Talari and was officially adopted on January 1, 2009.

Miehikkälä's coat of arms is the only one in the Kymenlaakso region to feature a letter-based design. The double-bent scythe forms the letter ‘M,’ symbolizing the municipality's name. The colors of the coat of arms are distinct from those of other Kymenlaakso coats of arms (which typically use silver, black, and blue) as well as from those of Virolahde and the former Kuusankoski. These colors are derived from the Coat of Arms of Karelia, highlighting Miehikkälä's historical connection to the province of Karelia. The heraldic description is: ‘In a red field, a silver double-bent scythe.’ It was designed by Tapio Vallioja in 1956.

The design incorporates elements from the coat of arms of the Creutz family, who historically owned large estates and several manors in the region. The silver crosses represent Pyhtää's role as the parent parish of four surrounding districts, and may also reference its ecclesiastical heritage. The salmon symbolize fishing and maritime activities. Crossed salmon also appeared in the seals of the Kymin district, which included the Pyhtää area during the Russian period. Earlier Swedish-era seals depicted a single leaping salmon, which was later adopted in the coats of arms of both Kymenlaakso and the Kymin municipality. The heraldic description is: ‘In a black field, two silver salmon with red fins, arranged crosswise, each accompanied by a silver Greek cross in the corners.’ It was designed by herald Ahti Hammar in 1951.

The elements of the coat of arms symbolize Virolahti's historic port, its fishing and maritime activities, trade, agriculture, and its status as home to one of the oldest parishes in the Kymenlaakso region. The color scheme, based on the Coat of Arms of Karelia, reflects the municipality's location within the historical province of Karelia. The Virolahti coat of arms closely resembles that of Paimio, a municipality in southwestern Finland. The blazon reads: ‘In a red field with a golden clover sowing, a silver anchor on a pole.’ It was designed by herald Olof Eriksson in 1951.
